reasoning: The critique targets a load-bearing component of the position: the “value is (approximately) multiplicative across many relatively independent dimensions” picture used to motivate fragility and rarity of mostly-great futures. If independence/weak correlation failed broadly, the toy-model intuition and some of the fragility argument would be significantly weakened, so centrality is moderately high (though the position also has other supports—e.g., moral-view fussiness/scale arguments—that would still push toward narrow targets even without strict independence). The objection has moderate strength: pointing to shared institutional/governance ‘latent variables’ plausibly induces correlations and could enlarge the target, but it’s not shown that correlations are strong enough, predominantly positive, and spanning the key dimensions (some tradeoffs may be negatively correlated: e.g., maximizing scale vs minimizing suffering; digital rights vs human-value primacy; diversity vs efficiency). Also, the original essay does not rely exclusively on an “independent uniforms” model; it presents it as a toy model/illustration, so undermining it doesn’t fully refute the broader ‘single-flaw can dominate’ claim. Correctness is fairly high: it is true in general that correlations can dramatically change product-like fragility and that many moral risk factors share causal roots; however, the critique overstates with “often automatically avoid many” and “destroy” without argument, so not fully correct. It is clear and tightly focused with minimal fluff, hence high clarity, low dead weight, and it largely stays on one issue. Overall impact is limited-to-moderate (roughly centrality×strength), so overall is mid-low.
title: Correlated institutional choices make the eutopia target larger than the product model suggests
